data.title: Triple Crown winners: List of horses that won Derby, Preakness, Belmont
data.meta_description: A Triple Crown is right up there among the greatest accomplishments in sports – there's a reason it took 37 years between Affirmed's sweep in 1978 and American Pharoah's triumph in 2015.
data.text:
A Triple Crown is right up there among the greatest accomplishments in sports – there’s a reason it took 37 years between Affirmed’s sweep in 1978 and American Pharoah’s triumph in 2015.

But how many horses have won the Triple Crown? In the 148-year history of the Kentucky Derby, only 13 horses have gone on to win the Preakness Stakes and Belmont Stakes and claim a Triple Crown.

All distances are 1 1/4 miles for Kentucky Derby, 1 3/16 miles for Preakness and 1 1/2 miles for Belmont unless otherwise noted:

1919

Sir Barton

Sir Barton was the first winner back in 1919, before the term “Triple Crown” had even been coined. An underdog coming into the race, Sir Barton led every step of the way in the 45th Kentucky Derby and went on to become the first horse to take all three competitions.

Jockey: Johnny Loftus

Owner: Commander J.K.L. Ross

Trainer: H.G. Bedwell

Derby time: 2:09 4/5

Preakness time: 1:53 (1 1/8 miles)

Belmont time: 2:17 2/5 (1 3/8 miles)

1930

Gallant Fox

The next sweep occurred 11 years later by Gallant Fox in 1930, under the tutelage of Jim Fitzsimmons, a Hall of Fame trainer.

Jockey: Earl Sande

Owner: Belair Stud

Trainer: James Fitzsimmons

Derby time: 2:07 3/5

Preakness time: 2:00 3/5

Belmont time: 2:31 3/5

1935

Omaha

From the first crop of Gallant Fox, Omaha has for nearly nine decades held the distinction of being the only Triple Crown winner sired by another.

Jockey: Willie Saunders

Owner: Belair Stud

Trainer: James Fitzsimmons

Derby time: 2:05

Preakness time: 1:58 2/5

Belmont time: 2:30 3/5

1937

War Admiral

War Admiral – the offspring of Man o’ War and Seabiscuit’s competition in the iconic “Race of the Century” – pulled off the feat in 1937 on his way to becoming one of the most successful thoroughbreds in the history of the sport.

Jockey: Charles Kurtsinger

Owner: Glen Riddle Farms

Trainer: George Conway

Derby time: 2:03 1/5

Preakness time: 1:58 2/5

Belmont time: 2:28 3/5

1941

Whirlaway

Whirlaway ran a record-setting 1941 Kentucky Derby, winning by eight lengths (the largest margin in Derby history) while establishing a new record time of 2:01 2/5.

Jockey: Eddie Arcaro

Owner: Calumet Farm

Trainer: Ben A. Jones

Derby time: 2:01 2/5

Preakness time: 1:58 4/5

Belmont time: 2:31

1943

Count Fleet

The 1943 Kentucky Derby was nearly canceled due to wartime restrictions on gasoline and transportation. Run for local spectators only, the “Streetcar Derby” was easily won by Count Fleet.

Jockey: Johnny Longden

Owner: Mrs. John D. Hertz

Trainer: Don Cameron

Derby time: 2:04

Preakness time: 1:57 2/5

Belmont time: 2:28 1/5

1946

Assault

Assault won the Kentucky Derby by a record-equaling eightlengths, won the Preakness by a neck, and captured the Belmont Stakes by a marginof three lengths, all in the span of four weeks.

Jockey: Warren Mehrtens

Owner: King Ranch

Trainer: Max Hirsch

Derby time: 2:06 3/5

Preakness time: 2:01 2/5

Belmont time: 2:30 4/5

1948

Citation

Citation became the second Triple Crown winner for Calumet Farm in 1948. The bay horse established a modern-day record, winning 16 straight races.

Jockey: Eddie Arcaro

Owner: Calumet Farm

Trainer: Ben A. Jones

Derby time: 2:05 2/5

Preakness time: 2:02 2/5

Belmont time: 2:28 1/5

1973

Secretariat

Arguably the greatest horse of alltime, Secretariat won the 1973 Kentucky Derby. Nicknamed “Big Red” for his reddish-browncolor, Secretariat broke several records in his 16 month racing career.

Jockey: Ron Turcotte

Owner: Meadow Stable

Trainer: Lucien Laurin

Derby time: 1:59 2/5

Preakness time: 1:53

Belmont time: 2:24

1977

Seattle Slew

Seattle Slew went on to win it four years later in 1977. Also considered one of the greatest racers in the sport’s history, Seattle Slew sired 1984 Kentucky Derby-winner Swale and many of his descendants are still on the track in 2018.

Jockey: Jean Cruguet

Owner: Karen L. Taylor

Trainer: William H. Turner

Derby time: 2:02 1/5

Preakness time: 1:54 2/5

Belmont time: 2:29 3/5

1978

Affirmed

Just one year later, Affirmed pulled off the sweep in 1978. A descendant of War Admiral, Affirmed is believed to have won over $2 million in his successful career.

Jockey: Steve Cauthen

Owner: Harbor View Farm

Trainer: Lazaro Barrera

Derby time: 2:01 1/5

Preakness time: 1:54 2/5

Belmont time: 2:26 4/5

2015

American Pharoah

That was it for 37 years – the sport went so long without another champ that some started to wonder if the feat would ever be accomplished again. And then, in 2015, American Pharoah happened. Trained by Bob Baffert and with jockey Victor Espinoza aboard, American Pharoah wrapped up his career with a victory in the 2015 Breeders’ Cup Classic and now resides in retirement at Ashford Stud near Lexington.

Jockey: Victor Espinoza

Owner: Zayat Stables

Trainer: Bob Baffert

Derby time: 2:03.02

Preakness time: 1:58.46

Belmont time: 2:26.65

2018

Justify

Another Baffert-trained colt joined the exclusive three years after American Pharoah. Justify in 2018 ran away with a win in the wettest Kentucky Derby in history, came out on top in the fog and mud in the Preakness and then wrapped it up with a decisive victory in the Belmont. Baffert joined Fitzsimmons in the record books with his second Triple Crown win.

Jockey: Mike E. Smith

Owner: China Horse Club, Head of Plains Partners LLC, Starlight Racing, WinStar Farm

Trainer: Bob Baffert

Derby time: 2:04.20

Preakness time: 1:55.93

Belmont time: 2:28.18
